exercise: Force
A contact force that acts perpendicular (at a right angle) to the surface of contact.
Magnitude
The alteration of an object's form, which can be temporary or permanent, due to applied forces.
Direction
The strength or size of a force, which is a vector quantity indicating how much force is applied.
Contact Forces
Forces that occur when objects are physically touching each other.
Frictional Force
A push or pull acting upon an object as a result of its interaction with another object.
Tension Force
The increase in the speed of an object when a net force is applied in the direction of that force.
Normal Force
A contact force that opposes the motion of an object and acts parallel to the surface in contact.
Applied Force
A type of frictional force that opposes the motion of objects moving through air.
Air Resistance
The attraction between two masses, such as the Earth and an object, causing it to fall.
Non-Contact Forces
The force that holds protons and neutrons together in an atomic nucleus, acting over very short distances.
Gravitational Force
A force that acts between charged particles or magnets, which can be attractive or repulsive.
Electromagnetic Force
Forces that act on an object without any physical contact.
Nuclear Force
The line along which something moves or faces; in physics, it is crucial to understanding the effect of forces.
Acceleration
The force exerted on an object by a person or another object.
Deceleration
A contact force transmitted through a string, rope, or cable when it is pulled tight by forces acting on it.
Change in Direction
The decrease in speed of an object when a net force acts in the opposite direction of its motion.
Change in Shape
The alteration of an object's path due to the influence of forces, without necessarily changing its speed.
